title: Ketan Patel

fields.name: Ketan Patel
fields.known_for: Co-founder and CEO of Greater Pacific Capital; chair of the Force for Good Initiative; lead of the UNCTAD-hosted Future Capital initiative working group on the future of capital and financing the 2030 Agenda; writings on geopolitics, technology and capital allocation
fields.alma_mater: London School of Economics; City University Business School (MBA)
fields.organization: Greater Pacific Capital; Force for Good Initiative

lead:
'''Ketan Patel''' (born February 1962) is a British strategist, investor, and author. He is the chief executive and co-founder of the private equity firm ''Greater Pacific Capital'' (GPC) and chair of the Force for Good Initiative, which publishes research and reports on capital allocation, technology, and sustainable development.<ref name="R58" /><ref name="R147" /><ref name="R146" /><ref name="R180" />

In 2019–2020, Patel was described by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) as the lead of the Future Capital initiative, a working group convened with the UN Office for Partnerships and the World Academy of Art & Science (WAAS) to develop proposals on how capital and finance could be allocated in support of the UN Secretary-General's financing strategy for the 2030 Agenda.<ref name="R195" /><ref name="R196" />

Patel is the author of ''The Master Strategist'' (2005) and has published on great-power transitions, sustainable development finance, climate policy, and global systemic risk in outlets including ''Frontiers in Political Science'', ''Frontiers in Environmental Economics'', ''Cadmus'', and Reuters.<ref name="R145" /><ref name="R174" /><ref name="R197" /><ref name="R161" /><ref name="R176" /><ref name="R188" />

sections.heading: Early life and education
sections.wikitext: UK Companies House records list Patel's date of birth as February 1962.<ref name="R186" /> In a 2005 profile, ''The Independent'' reported that Patel studied at the London School of Economics and City University Business School.<ref name="R58" /> Greater Pacific Capital's website states that he earned a BSc in Economics from the London School of Economics and an MBA from City University Business School, and describes him as a qualified accountant; it also states that he holds a postgraduate degree in neuroscience from King's College London.<ref name="R62" />

sections.heading: Career
sections.wikitext:
===Early career===
After qualifying as an accountant, Patel worked at KPMG and later joined Goldman Sachs.<ref name="R58" /> A 2005 profile in ''The Independent'' described him as having been head of strategy at Goldman Sachs before leaving the firm to establish his own consultancy and investment business.<ref name="R58" /> Publisher and conference biographies have described him as having led Goldman Sachs' Strategic Group and referred to him as the firm's "chief futurologist".<ref name="R190" /><ref name="R173" /><ref name="UWGa70nSfcQ" />

===Greater Pacific Capital===
Patel is the co-founder and chief executive of the private equity firm Greater Pacific Capital (GPC).<ref name="R147" /><ref name="R187" /> The UK Companies House register lists him as a designated member of Greater Pacific Capital LLP since April 2005.<ref name="R186" /> Media coverage of GPC has included reporting on an India-focused fundraise and portfolio investments in education technology, electric vehicles and artificial intelligence.<ref name="R147" /><ref name="R150" /><ref name="R151" /><ref name="R153" /><ref name="R169" /><ref name="R170" /><ref name="R171" /> Business press has also reported on a US$125 million commitment by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) to one of GPC's funds.<ref name="R202" />

===Force for Good Initiative===
Reuters has described Patel as the founder and chairman of Force for Good, which it says was established to support the UN Secretary-General's roadmap for sustainable development and that it examined and engaged 125 global financial institutions and 100 technology companies in its research programmes.<ref name="R187" /><ref name="R188" /> The initiative publishes report series including ''Capital as a Force for Good'' and ''Technology as a Force for Good''.<ref name="R178" /><ref name="R179" /> Coverage by the International Institute for Sustainable Development's SDG Knowledge Hub summarized findings from the technology report and its relevance to the SDGs.<ref name="R180" /> In a conversation hosted by the London School of Economics' LSE IDEAS programme, Patel described Force for Good as using the UN Sustainable Development Goals as a benchmark to assess global capital flows and identify potential solutions aimed at increasing investment in areas of need, including in the Global South.<ref name="q7P830q08VY" />

===International initiatives and affiliations===
Patel has served as a trustee of the World Academy of Art and Science and has published with its journal ''Cadmus''.<ref name="R176" /> UNCTAD reporting on the Future Capital initiative identified Patel as the working group's lead and described the group as developing a draft report on how capital can be deployed as a "force for good" in support of the 2030 Agenda.<ref name="R195" /><ref name="R196" /> He has been listed as a member of the advisory board of the "United Nations at LSE" programme (LSE IDEAS) in his capacity as CEO of the Force for Good Initiative.<ref name="R193" /> In 2024, the Maryam Forum announced Patel as its special adviser for a programme on global governance and the future of leadership.<ref name="R200" /> He has also been listed as a member of the Senior Working Group for the Sustainable Development Solutions Network (SDSN) and as a participant in an SDSN European Green Deal hub working group.<ref name="R198" /><ref name="R199" />

sections.heading: Public speaking and media
sections.wikitext: Patel has appeared in recorded interviews, keynote lectures and conference panels on geopolitics, technology, capital allocation and sustainable development, including SALT Talks interviews and related event materials. These have included a lecture at London's Guildhall for an "Incredible India"-branded event,<ref name="syovYnlRfWE" /> a presentation at the International Conference on Sustainable Development (ICSD) focused on sustainable finance and investment in the Global South,<ref name="XxL8bEEoq6c" /> and a COP29 side-event session convened by the Force for Good Initiative on mobilising capital for SDG progress.<ref name="PrQG-ixeDy8" /> <ref name="R172" />

sections.heading: Ideas and contributions
sections.wikitext:
Patel's published work has focused on systemic risk and transition in the international order, with particular emphasis on the interaction of geopolitics, technology and capital allocation.

===Great-power transitions and the international order===
In a peer-reviewed article in ''Frontiers in Political Science'', Patel and co-authors argued that major powers tend to pass through identifiable life-cycle phases and assessed implications for U.S. strategic positioning and alliance structures.<ref name="R174" />

In a 2023 lecture hosted in the Lord Mayor's "Knowledge Miles" series at Gresham College, Patel framed the early 21st century as a period of overlapping transitions—including demographic growth, a shift toward multipolarity, and changes in technology and labor markets—and argued that these shifts would affect trade, capital, population, information and energy flows.<ref name="R194" /><ref name="PK-qz7lQ4nQ" />

In a panel discussion hosted by the World Academy of Art and Science, Patel described contemporary "global turbulence" in terms of multiple long-run "cycles" operating simultaneously, including climate cycles, shifts in economic eras (from industrial to information/technology), and changes in global power structures.<ref name="MG4y2KUlclU" />

In a 2020 SALT interview series hosted by SALT, Patel argued that historical empires tend to follow recurring rise-and-fall patterns and discussed the possibility of the United States moving from a period of predominance toward a shared-power system. In the same interview, he described what he called a "quadrilateral" structure of major power blocs—framed around the United States, China, India and the European Union—and argued that their interaction would increasingly shape global trade and rules-setting.<ref name="UWGa70nSfcQ" />

In a panel discussion on investment opportunities along the "New Silk Road", Patel characterized the initiative as linking Europe and Asia through both physical and digital infrastructure and argued that investors assess countries across the corridor according to factors including the enforceability of law, currency convertibility, and sectoral regulatory ground rules.<ref name="Z2YsxpHQez4" />

===Sustainable development finance and capital allocation===
In ''Cadmus'', Patel and co-authors argued that meeting the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is constrained less by the absolute availability of capital than by capital allocation mechanisms, incentives and risk pricing.<ref name="R161" /> In a Reuters commentary, Patel argued that scaling proven solutions and mobilising capital at commercial scale are central to closing SDG funding gaps.<ref name="R188" /> Stefan Brunnhuber later described the paper as a "seminal" and "highly novel" contribution in an article responding to it.<ref name="R184" />

In a 2022 keynote address at an "SDG Investment Fair", Patel argued that SDG-related projects are often treated as "worthy causes" rather than commercial opportunities, and that investor concerns (including currency, regulatory, execution, exit and ESG-related risks) can raise required returns and limit capital flows to lower-income countries.<ref name="nzU-2VQtfmI" />

In a panel discussion on sustainability performance and metrics, Patel argued that global investable capital exists but is not structured to flow to areas of greatest need, and that risk–return incentives tend to steer investment toward established markets rather than lower-income countries. In the same discussion, he said his analysis at Force for Good includes the geography and sectoral distribution of SDG-related finance and argued that technology solutions are being developed and deployed unevenly, with lower adoption in parts of the Global South.<ref name="BJOuimJlSs4" />

In a panel at SALT on sustainability and capital allocation, Patel framed SDG financing as partly an investment opportunity tied to the inclusion of underserved populations and argued that technology can lower the cost of serving those markets.<ref name="vXiOrcfPAcI" />

In a panel discussion on financing implementation of the SDGs hosted by the World Academy of Art and Science as part of its "Global Leadership for the 21st Century" series, Patel argued that there is no "lack of money" globally, but that financing depends on regulation and incentives, standard-setting to reduce "SDG-washing", and innovation in instruments (including debt-related tools).<ref name="vdNREXocbJs" />

In an ICSD 2022 plenary session on financing implementation of the SDGs and the European Green Deal, Patel said his analysis at Force for Good suggested SDG financing requirements and the SDG financing gap had increased compared with earlier estimates, and argued that capital-allocation changes would require alignment among households, governments, the financial sector and corporations. He also said Force for Good's research found an association between more extensive sustainability activity and higher shareholder returns (as presented in the session).<ref name="o4g_83HuXJ0" />

===Energy transition, externalities and future energy systems===
In a COP29-related interview clip published by Force for Good, Patel argued that current accounting and market pricing does not fully incorporate environmental externalities, and suggested that regulators determine rules for pricing such costs.<ref name="sCTnMHbMlGk" /> In the same interview, he described fossil fuels as having enabled industrial prosperity but argued that an immediate shut-off would be destabilizing, and said he expected a further breakthrough toward a clean and abundant energy source within "the next decade" or "decade and a half".<ref name="sCTnMHbMlGk" />

In a COP29 dialogue session on innovation for climate and sustainability action, Patel discussed the role of incentives in capital allocation and, using India as an example, argued that investors see the country as having underlying macroeconomic "drivers" including urbanization, changing income distribution, and increasing internet use (as stated in the discussion).<ref name="IzWgfBIiaZ4" /> In the same panel, he argued that investor returns in India have been difficult to achieve consistently because, in his view, the pool of managers with differentiated capabilities is relatively limited and market volatility can be high; he said that protecting capital and managing risk were important factors for limited partners selecting managers (as stated in the discussion).<ref name="IzWgfBIiaZ4" />

In a COP29 dialogue session on innovation for climate and sustainability action, Patel argued that climate policy faced constraints in public and electoral politics and said that, in his reading of the IPCC reports, existing policies did not put the world on track to limit warming to 2.5 °C. In the same discussion, he said the financial system was structured to serve only part of the global population and argued that investment into lower-income markets is constrained by investor assessments of regulatory stability, currency controls, and exit/liquidity conditions (as stated in the session).<ref name="ezdcZ5AsFdc" />

===Artificial intelligence and investment===
In a 2023 panel discussion about whether investment in AI resembled a bubble, Patel argued that AI was "foundational" rather than a short-term bubble, and described the technology as a hybrid of human and machine capabilities (which he termed "augmented" intelligence rather than "artificial" intelligence).<ref name="SLzI6WBvUnw" /> In the same discussion, he argued that current AI systems were better described as tools for searching and structuring information than as systems with human-like contextual understanding or emotion, while also describing the technology as economically transformative and widely applicable across sectors including healthcare, education, financial services and research (as stated in the panel).<ref name="SLzI6WBvUnw" />

===Global turbulence and polycrisis frameworks===
In 2025, Patel co-authored a series of ''Cadmus'' articles proposing conceptual frameworks for understanding "global turbulence" and policy responses to interlinked crises across security, development and governance.<ref name="R176" /><ref name="R175" />

===Cognitive sovereignty and information-era security===
A 2025 SSRN preprint by Patel examined what it termed "cognitive empires" and the strategic implications of algorithmic influence and AI systems for autonomy and security.<ref name="R177" />

===Climate policy, COP processes and finance===
In ''Frontiers in Environmental Economics'', Patel and co-authors examined the economic and governance implications of the 2023 UN Climate Change Conference (COP28), including what they described as gaps between stated commitments and implementation pathways.<ref name="R197" />

===Technology and development pathways===
In Force for Good reports, Patel and collaborators have argued that digital technologies could materially accelerate progress toward sustainable development targets when paired with governance and investment frameworks.<ref name="R179" /><ref name="R180" />

In a panel on global trade and investment "megatrends", Patel argued that recent shocks had reduced the usefulness of extrapolating past trends in planning, and that large, apparently isolated events could substantially reshape capital flows and priorities, including financing for the SDGs.<ref name="D1FeMgmEnbY" />

In a 2023 conference session on "education for human security" (World Academy of Art and Science), Patel presented the Human Security for All campaign as an attempt to translate the UN Sustainable Development Goals into a more accessible framework. He described the campaign in terms of seven "pillars"—food security, healthcare, economic security, environmental protection, personal safety and mobility, community security, and political freedom—and argued that a simpler framing could help technology firms and other organizations connect their activities to human-security outcomes.<ref name="AM4p8kAazg8" />

In the same session, Patel argued that technology could help expand access to education and other services, and said that "40" SDG targets could be addressed through technology transfer; he cited UNICEF work on providing internet-like access to education in remote areas as an example of implementation approaches discussed in the session.<ref name="AM4p8kAazg8" />

In a separate talk on the "future of money", Patel argued that the "character" of capital depends on its sources and associated obligations, and that the digitization of finance can disintermediate traditional institutions and enable more peer-to-peer transactions. He also argued that political debates framed as "socialism" versus "capitalism" were less descriptive of how money functions in an information-era context, and described digitization as expanding the range of assets and services that can be monetized and traded.<ref name="fsbiQ5Y9j2E" />

In a 2025 CES panel discussion on technology and the developing world, Patel argued that falling technology costs and profit incentives would push firms toward "new markets" and "new customers", and that policy and cultural context can affect adoption. In the same discussion, he cited India's digital identity-linked system as an example of technology-enabled financial inclusion, describing it as enabling hundreds of millions of people to open bank accounts over several years (as stated in the panel).<ref name="4sXj29SkAA8" />

In a 2025 CES interview focused on Force for Good's technology report, Patel described what he called a "fierce competition" among states in technology development, arguing that leadership in key technologies tends to correlate with geopolitical influence. In the same interview, he said Force for Good's research identified "19 technologies" that were ready to deploy and argued that practical barriers—including market size, governance, regulatory constraints for investors, and currency convertibility—can slow adoption in lower-income markets.<ref name="CU2nlM0Pyxc" />

===Risk, insurance and resilience===
In a recorded interview for a series on "the future of capitalism", Patel discussed risk and resilience with Bruce Carnegie-Brown (chairman of Lloyd's of London). In the interview, Patel raised risks associated with climate change and climate-driven migration, and argued that a substantial share of the Sustainable Development Goals financing gap could potentially be reduced through the transfer and application of existing technologies.<ref name="bGYwvYotujQ" />

sections.heading: Influence and reception
sections.wikitext:
Publisher material for ''The Master Strategist'' includes endorsement quotations attributed to Nelson Mandela and Nandan Nilekani.<ref name="R181" /> Speaker biographies for Patel at events including a Z/Yen Group webinar and the Doha Forum have described the book as having a foreword by Nelson Mandela.<ref name="R194" /><ref name="R191" /><ref name="R192" /> A review of the book appeared in the ''IMFO'' journal (Institute of Municipal Finance Officers).<ref name="R185" />

In academic and policy-adjacent forums, Patel's work on SDG finance has been cited by other authors in ''Cadmus''; for example, Stefan Brunnhuber described Patel and co-authors' SDG-financing paper as "seminal" and "highly novel" in an article responding to its argument.<ref name="R184" /> Patel has also published commentaries through Reuters on the SDGs and global development finance.<ref name="R188" /><ref name="R189" />

UNCTAD reporting on the Future Capital initiative stated that participants considered the working group's draft report "unprecedented" in defining activities that could make an entity or industry a "force for good" and described the project as having potential to support UN work on advancing investment in the SDGs.<ref name="R196" />

In a 2023 introduction to a Lord Mayor's "Knowledge Miles" lecture, the session chair described Patel as "a senior figure in the City of London" and introduced him as chief executive and co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital and founder and chairman of Force for Good.<ref name="PK-qz7lQ4nQ" />

In an LSE IDEAS discussion, the moderator introduced Patel as chair of Force for Good, a former head of Goldman Sachs' Strategic Group, and a co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital.<ref name="q7P830q08VY" />

In a 2019 conference panel introduction, the moderator introduced Patel as "CEO and Founder" of Greater Pacific Capital.<ref name="Z2YsxpHQez4" />

In a 2025 CES panel on technology and the developing world, a panelist (Walt Stinson) referred to Patel's "Force for Good" group as having published a technology report and described it as a "132-page" report intended to inform industry planning (as stated in the discussion).<ref name="4sXj29SkAA8" />

In a 2025 CES interview, the interviewer described Patel as leading "Force for Good" and "Pacific Capital" (in reference to Greater Pacific Capital).<ref name="CU2nlM0Pyxc" />

At the opening of a 2023 World Academy of Art and Science online conference session, the moderator introduced Patel as "co-founder and CEO" of Greater Pacific Capital and chair of Force for Good.<ref name="AM4p8kAazg8" />

sections.heading: Personal life
sections.wikitext: A 2005 profile in ''The Independent'' noted that Patel lived in London and described his interest in meditation and long-distance running.<ref name="R58" />

sections.heading: Selected works
sections.wikitext:
* ''Who Knows Wins: Using Information to Make Better, Faster Decisions'' (Office for the Book & Notable Books, 1996).<ref name="R201" />
* ''The Master Strategist: Power, Purpose and Principle'' (Hutchinson, 2005).<ref name="R145" /><ref name="R183" />
* ''The Master Strategist: Power, Purpose and Principle in Action'' (Arrow, 2007).<ref name="R181" /><ref name="R183" />
* ''The Master Strategist'' (Cornerstone Digital, e-book, 2011).<ref name="R182" />
* "American hegemony at a critical juncture, lessons from history's great powers" (with Christian Hansmeyer, Nandan Desai and Aditya Ajit), ''Frontiers in Political Science'' (2025).<ref name="R174" />
* "Funding the Sustainable Development Goals is Not a Challenge of Sufficient Capital" (with Christian Hansmeyer, Nandan Desai and Aditya Ajit), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R161" />
* "Sources and Solutions for Global Turbulence" (with Garry Jacobs), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R176" />
* "Turbulent Times: A Framework for Navigating Global Crisis Through Conscious Transformation" (with Christian Hansmeyer), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R175" />
* "The Rising Age of Cognitive Empires: Colonising the Mind" (preprint), SSRN (2025).<ref name="R177" />
* "The impact of COP28 on energy policy and the global economy" (with Christian Hansmeyer, Nandan Desai and Aditya Ajit), ''Frontiers in Environmental Economics'' (2024).<ref name="R197" />
* "Comment: How to overcome the $137 trillion shortfall to fund the Global Goals" (Reuters commentary, 2023).<ref name="R188" />
* "Comment: How to invest for impact and returns" (Reuters commentary, 2024).<ref name="R189" />

sections.heading: Further reading
sections.wikitext:
* Nissel, Jason (29 May 2005). "Ketan Patel and Thomas Friedman: Just stop the world, so the West can get off". ''The Independent''.<ref name="R58" />
* "Greater Pacific Capital hits first close of $300 million in $700 million India-focused fund". ''Mint'' (6 August 2018).<ref name="R147" />
* Ghosh, Nirmal (17 September 2021). "UN faces US$100t shortfall in fight against climate change, inequality". ''The Business Times''.<ref name="R144" />
* "Force for Good Report Explores Role of Technology in Helping Reach SDGs". SDG Knowledge Hub (International Institute for Sustainable Development) (2 February 2023).<ref name="R180" />
* United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) (2019–2020). "Future Capital" initiative coverage and launch reporting.<ref name="R195" /><ref name="R196" />

notability_signals: Chair and project lead of Force for Good report series; covered by SDG Knowledge Hub (International Institute for Sustainable Development)
Independent review of The Master Strategist (IMFO)
Invited speaker and interview subject in recorded forums (SALT, CES, WAAS, COP29 and other conferences)
Named as CEO/co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital in business press coverage (e.g., Mint; The Business Times)
Peer-reviewed publication in Frontiers in Political Science (2025)
Publisher pages include endorsement quotations from prominent public figures for The Master Strategist
Reuters author page and published Reuters sustainability commentaries
UNCTAD coverage identifying Patel as lead of the Future Capital initiative (2019–2020)
gaps_to_fill: Birthplace (and full birthdate) from a reliable published biographical source suitable for Wikipedia infobox use.
Additional substantial independent profiles synthesizing Patel’s career and influence beyond deal coverage and event materials.
